Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Class on a Chip
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I Class on a Chip project aims to advance science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education for a broad range of students through the innovative application of micro-devices that are used to teach fundamental physics and engineering principles as well as micro- and nano-technology concepts. An array of individually computer controllable micro-devices on a chip is the centerpiece of the system, will allow numerous laboratory experiments and demonstrations to be carried out under a microscope.

This Class on a Chip project gives professors, teachers and students access to the micro and nano world at a relatively low cost. By providing teachers with hardware, software and supporting curriculum, this framework will impact hundreds and thousands of students by allowing them to become immersed in essential scientific and engineering concepts, thus propelling a larger fraction of students towards scientific careers in the STEM fields. Universities with and without substantial micro-device initiatives and resources will also benefit for this accessible technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through NSF SBIR Phase I funding, Class on a Chip, Inc. has made significant progress in establishing the commercial feasibility of an educational system known as Class on a Chip. The Class on a Chip System is intended for use in physics, engineering, and technology laboratories at colleges and high schools. The System is used to teach fundamental STEM concepts. It is also used for instruction in micro and nano technologies. An array of individually computer controllable MEMS (Microelectromechanical Systems) devices on a chip is the primary component of the system. Up to 16 devices are available for conducting numerous laboratory experiments and demonstrations. The System incorporates state-of-the-art components, but is accessible to a broad range of education levels. The System is designed to provide relatively low-cost access to the micro and nano realm, permitting broad utilization and flexibility. Both high school and college versions of the lab manual were developed, along with a teacher’s guide. The difficulty level of the labs is controlled by the questions and the math required.

Figure 1 shows the power supply and packaged MEMS Education Chip. The 3 mm x 6 mm MEMS chip is fabricated in a foundry process (SUMMiT V) at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, NM. A design view of the chip is shown in Figure 2. In Figure 3, an electron microscope image shows a 1 mm diameter micromotor coupled to a gear. The micromotor and other devices move in response to electrical signals that are controlled by the user through intuitive, on-screen dials and switches. The movement can be viewed through a digital microscope which sends video to the computer monitor. Figure 4 shows the graphical user interface controls and the digital video.
